ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜. â‰  Â»verb phraseÂ»[ğ“ŸÂ»'say' + ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Â»cont] they say, he/she says; they were saying, he/she was saying; they/he/she said (postverbal singular or plural marker of reported information deriving from person[s] who is/are present and not moving).Â»['Moving' here means 'changing location'; motions or gestures that do not change the entity's location in horizontal space do not take this affix.] ğ“ªğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“ªğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Â»the cook says there are no potatoes (RRBn1-43).

ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ. â‰  Â»verbÂ»[regularÂ£,Â»ğ“˜_ğ“§ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ] (transitive)Â»be bothered or annoyed by, be irritated by; find bothersome (dn/fh980930; FH/11/19/01/pc). ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“µğ“£). verbÂ»[regularÂ£+syncopatingÂ£,Â»ğ“˜_ğ“§ğ“ªÍ˜_ğ“µğ“£Í˜Â»(first or second slot in verb may optionally remain unconjugated)] (transitive)Â»forget; leave behindÂ»(01/30/95/FH/pc:prod; orig; FH/07/09/01/pc). ğ“˜ğ“·ğ“£ğ“§ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“œğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ŸÂ»I'll never forget you (01/12/95/FH/pc). ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“œğ“£Í˜Â»I forgot. ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“œğ“£Â»I forget.Â»ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“£Í˜Â»you forget. ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ŸÂ»you didn't forget it (01/30/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.50). ğ“°ğ“ªğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“£Í˜ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£ğ“ŸÂ»you forgot to bring back potatoes. ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£ğ“§ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜Â»he forgot you (FH:5/02/96/prod). ğ““ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»John forgets. ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“£ğ“§ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ ğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ŸÂ»we'll never forget you (FH:5/02/96/prod). ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“¸ğ“˜Â»we forget (RBnot-nd-1/10; 01/30/95/FH/pc:ok). ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“£Í˜Â»don't forget it [said to one person] (RBn10-7:JW). ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ!Â»don't forget it! ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ â‰  . reportativeÂ»[ğ“ŸÂ»'say' + ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜Â»cont] they say or are saying or were saying; he/she says or is saying or was saying (indicates that information in the sentence is or was reported by another or others).Â»ğ“©ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜ ğ“ªğ“¤'ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¬ğ“£ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“œğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“™Â»people say I'm hard to get along with (RBn17-p02). ğ“©ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“¬ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜Â»those people coming there are just hollering, they're saying (01/04/95/FH/pc:okc; FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). Carolyn ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“·ğ“Ÿğ“µğ“¶ğ“¸ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“™Â»Carolyn is going to a wedding [they say] (02/27/95/JS/pc). ğ“·ğ“£ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“Ÿğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“£ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“™Â»Sonny knows Osage, that's what they're saying. ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¸ğ“¬ğ“¶ğ“¨ğ“š ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“ªğ“µğ“£ğ“²ğ“£Í˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“™Â»lightning and thunder are getting you [plural], they are saying (line from a children's song) (FH).

ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“£ğ“ŸÂ»[archaic], Ã¡ap, Ã©epe). reportativeÂ»[ğ“ŸÂ»'say' + ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“£Â»+ ğ“µğ“Ÿ] he/she/they said, it is said, known by hearsay (indicates that information in the sentence was reported by another or others; often used in ceremonial speech and in storytelling).Â»ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“£ ğ“²'ğ“Ÿğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»it is said that they are also killing children (RBn3-03). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“£ ğ“©ğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“£ğ“ŸÂ»they said you were a doctor [expected Mod. (01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“£ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ?Â»when are you all going to come see us? ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜. â‰  Â»noun Â»(location) on theÂ»other sideÂ»(FH:4/18/96/tape). ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ ğ“£ğ“¬ğ“¯ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£ğ“ŸÂ»they went right past us [on the other side] but didn't speak to us (RB-MSB 4/7/83; FH:4/18/96/tape:okc). ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»you passed right by (FH:4/18/96/tape:prod).

ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜. â‰  Â»verbÂ»[syncopatingÂ£, ğ“˜_ğ“µğ“£Í˜] (transitive) have, own, possessÂ»(01/04/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.64). ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“ºğ“Ÿğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“ªğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“£Í˜ ğ“©ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ?Â»do you [sitting] have any money? ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“ºğ“Ÿğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“ªğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“£Í˜ ğ“µğ“šğ“¯ğ“Ÿ?Â»do you [moving] have any money? ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£. â‰  Â»verbÂ»[syncopatingÂ£+regularÂ£, ğ“˜_ğ“µğ“£Í˜(ğ“˜)_ğ“²ğ“£] [ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜Â»+ ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£] [initial ğ“˜Â»of ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£Â»is sometimes omitted in 3rd person forms] (transitive) bring here; arrive here with (motion accomplished). ğ“»ğ“˜Í˜ğ“©ğ“£ğ“Ÿğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“·ğ“£ğ“œğ“£Í˜ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ğ“ŸÂ»I brought you some candy. ğ“ªğ“©ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“œğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“ªğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“£Í˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ?Â»are you going to bring some food? ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜. â‰  contÂ»[often appears as ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»(from ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Â»+ ğ“µğ“ŸÂ»decl; ğ“µğ“ŸÂ»earlier characterized female speech)] continuative aspect postverbal marker (indicating ongoing action or state in present, past, or future time) for 3rd person singular or plural nonmoving subject that is present with speaker (contrast ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜).Â»['Moving' here means 'changing location'; ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜. â‰  Â»subject markerÂ»(follows a subject [singular or plural] that is not moving, including dead nonhuman animates [ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜Â»is used for dead humans] and is present with speaker or is an abstract entity; contrast ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜). ğ“˜ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“§ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“«ğ“¸ğ“Ÿ. â‰  Â»verb phraseÂ»turn around the other way; turn oneself the other way or to the other side; (metaphorically) begin to do right, mend your waysÂ»(RB). ğ“˜ğ“¨ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“©ğ“˜ ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“§ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“«ğ“¸ğ“˜Â»turn yourself around (BE2.146; FH:ok).

ğ“˜ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¯ğ“£ â‰  Â»(variant: ğ“˜ğ“¨ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“£). verbÂ»[conjug. unknown] [ğ“˜-Â»locÂ»+ ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¯ğ“£] (transitive) be on top of or above something else.Â»ğ“˜ğ“¨ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»he or she is upstairs (02/27/95/JS/pc:ok; BE2.147). â€¢ place something up or above.Â»ğ“˜ğ“¨ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“£ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»I'm going to put it up above (HRE/01/17/02/pc). â€¢ adverbÂ»up or up above, upstairs, in the upper part. ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“ªÂ»ğ“˜ğ“¨ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“£ ğ“¤ğ“£ ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ go up into the mountains. ğ“˜ğ“¨ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ she went upstairs (RB;Â»02/27/95/JS/pc:ok).

ğ“˜ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“°ğ“˜ â‰  Â»(variant of ğ“Ÿğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“°ğ“˜).

ğ“˜ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ. â‰  Â»verbÂ»[regularÂ£,Â»ğ“˜_ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ] (transitive) crawl on, crawl upon.Â»ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“ªğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»the baby is crawling on the floor.

ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£, ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£). verbÂ»[regularÂ£, ğ“˜_ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£] [ğ“˜-Â»locÂ»+ ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜] (transitive) stand on top of, be superior to in some quality (used in comparative and superlative constructions)Â»(MSB). ğ“®ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“²ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ, ğ“ºğ“˜ğ“©ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜Â»he's taller than everyone else (literally, 'he is tall, he stands atop others [in tallness]'). â€¢ step on, step in.Â»ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ you stepped in it. ğ“¨ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“°ğ“ªğ“®ğ“°ğ“ª ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜Â»you stepped in mud (FH:4/24/96/prod). ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¬ğ“£ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“œğ“˜Í˜ ğ“µğ“šğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»you must have stepped on something bad, because you're smelling bad (FH:prod). ğ“£Í˜ ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜Â»I stepped on a rock (BE2.127; 03/14/95/FH/pc:ok).

ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ â‰  (variant of ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ªğ“Ÿ).

ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜. â‰  Â»verbÂ»[regularÂ£, ğ“˜_ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜Â»] [ğ“˜-Â»locÂ»+ ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜] (transitive) listen to, heed (RBn10-6:JW). ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ [expected form: ğ“˜Í˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜Â»(from ğ“˜-ğ“˜Í˜-ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜)] listen to me [singular addressee] (02/16/95/FH/pc:okc; RBn2-moj/p23). ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“¬ğ“£Â»[expected form: ğ“˜Í˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“¬ğ“£] listen to me [plural addressee] (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok). ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“£Í˜ğ“¨ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“»ğ“£ğ“ŸÂ»I objected to it, but you didn't listen to me. ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»pray and he will hear [listen to] you. â€¢ (intransitive) listen. ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜, ğ“ªğ“·ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¡ğ“ŸÂ»are you listening, I'm talking to you (RBn19-05). ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“£, ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“ªğ“˜ ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¬ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“œğ“˜Â»listen [plural addressee], I want to say a few words (RBn23-17). ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜!Â»listen! (05/01/95/LS/pc).

ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜. â‰  Â»contÂ»[often appears as ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“™Â»(from ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜Â»+ ğ“µğ“ŸÂ»decl; ğ“µğ“ŸÂ»earlier characterized female speech)] continuative aspect postverbal marker (indicating ongoing action or state in present, past, or future time) for 3rd person singular or plural moving or absent subject (contrast ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜).Â»['Moving' here means 'changing location'; motions or gestures that do not change the entity's location in horizontal space do not take this affix.] ğ“Ÿ ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“£ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“™Â»he's doing it himself (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77). ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“µğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ he's wanting it. ğ“ªğ“¸ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“™Â»he has just lost it (02/13/95/FH/pc:okc; 04/14/95/FH/pc; RBnOT 2/10/83/p3). ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜. â‰  Â»subject markerÂ»(follows a subject [singular or plural] that is moving or is not present with speaker; contrast ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜).Â»['Moving' here means 'changing location'; motions or gestures that do not change the entity's location in horizontal space do not take this affix.] ğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“®ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“™Â»that rock is heavy; those rocks are heavy (the rocks are being carried in this instance, therefore are moving) (FH/07/31/01/pc). ğ“¡ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“¯ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“˜?Â»why is this dog moving around so much? ğ“¡ğ“¶ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“ªğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“™, ğ“²ğ“£ğ“§ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“¡ğ“£ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»a whole bunch of them were talking when the family came over (3/2/89/MSB). ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“·ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“ªğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»he got thrown off the horse (literally, 'the horse threw him') (RBn19-01). ğ“£ğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜Â»the mother [subject of sentence, if "up and around"] (2-1-50-2). ğ“·ğ“£ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“ºğ“Ÿğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“™Â»Sonny doesn't have any money [Sonny is absent]. â€¢ used for respect with deceased persons even if present (ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Â»is used with animals).Â»ğ“¯ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“²'ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»that man died (RBn22-17).

ğ“˜Í˜-. â‰  Â»prnmÂ»1st person singular patient pronominal, used as object of active verbs ('me', 'for me', 'to me', 'from me', etc.). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“Ÿğ“ºğ“Ÿ ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“¸ğ“˜Â»write a letter for me; write me a letter; write a letter to me (HHtape; 18a). ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“®ğ“¶ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“£Â»remember me. ğ“£ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“ŸÂ»you make me laugh. ğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“ªğ“˜Í˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜Â»he lives within my heart (04/04/99/FH/pc). ğ“ªğ“µğ“ªğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“Ÿ ğ“¯ğ“ğ“¶ğ“²'ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“ŸÂ»you can't make me behave (MJ 1-19-83). ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“©ğ“£ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“µğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“™Â»a whole bunch of them wanted/want cigarettes from me (3-2-140). â€¢ 1st person singular patient pronominal prefix, used as subject of stative verbs ('I').Â»ğ“˜Í˜ğ“®ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“ŸÂ»I'm tired. ğ“»ğ“˜Í˜ğ“©ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜Â»I like candy

ğ“˜Í˜- â‰  Â»(see Ä…k-). prnmÂ»1st person dual or plural agent pronominal ('we', subject). [This is the form taken by this prefix before consonants. It contracts with verb-initial ğ“£Â»to form ğ“˜Í˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜.]

ğ“˜Í˜ â‰  Â»(variant of ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“š?). interjectionÂ»yes (female speaking). ğ“˜Í˜, ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“£ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“²ğ“ŸÂ»okay, we'll do it [verb lacks 1st plural inflection] (RBn17-p03).

ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¡ğ“Ÿ â‰  (variant of ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¡ğ“Ÿ).

ğ“œğ“˜Í˜ â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“œğ“˜). verbÂ»[uninflected?] (intransitive) smell, emanate an odor, give off a fragrance.Â»ğ“œğ“˜ ğ“¬ğ“£ğ“»ğ“£Â»[it] smells bad (04/06/95/LS/pc:ok). ğ“œğ“˜ ğ“Ÿğ“»ğ“£Â»it smells odd (04/06/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.124). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“œğ“˜Í˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜ ğ“œğ“˜Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»he/she smells like perfume (RBn10-20). ğ“œğ“˜Í˜ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜ it smells good. ğ“œğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¬ğ“£ğ“»ğ“£ it smells bad. â€¢ noun Â»smell, odor, scentÂ»(03/02/95/FH/pc). ğ“œğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜Â»a pleasing smell, a fragrance. ğ“œğ“˜Í˜ğ“¬ğ“£ğ“»ğ“£ a bad odor.

ğ“œğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“˜. â‰  Â»adjectiveÂ»lean,Â»thin.Â»ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“¶ğ“Ÿ ğ“œğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“˜ pancakes, thin bread (03/20/95/FH/pc:ok).

ğ“œğ“£Í˜ â‰  Â»(variant: ğ“œğ“£Í˜ğ“Ÿ). verbÂ»[1st singular of ğ“µğ“£Í˜] (intransitive) I am, I was.Â»ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“œğ“£Í˜ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“œğ“˜ ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ŸÂ»that's the way I am, but I don't want to be that way (FH:08/22/96). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“Ÿ ğ“œğ“£Í˜Â»I'm Osage (RBn12-03). ğ“©ğ“£ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“œğ“£Í˜ğ“ŸÂ»I'm cold. ğ“¡ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“ºğ“˜ğ“©ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“¶ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ ğ“œğ“£Í˜ğ“ŸÂ»I ironed all day (FH:prod). ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“¤ğ“£ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“ŸÂ»I'm out of breath. ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“¤ğ“£ ğ“œğ“£ğ“ŸÂ»I'm out of breath [synonymous with preceding example] (FH). â€¢ I amÂ»characterized by (e.g., I have a certain condition). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“·ğ“Ÿğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“œğ“£Í˜Â»I see poorly (literally, 'I am of bad sight') (RB). â€¢ I am present, I was present.Â»ğ“¡ğ“ªğ“·ğ“šğ“¤ğ“£ ğ“µğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“œğ“£Í˜ ğ“©ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“£ ğ“Ÿğ“²ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜, ğ“·ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“Ÿ ğ“œğ“£Í˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“Ÿ ğ“Ÿğ“¯ğ“£ğ“ŸÂ»wherever two or three only are, I will always be [even] there, you said (Matt.18:20; FH:prayer). ğ“œğ“£Í˜ğ“ŸÂ»I'm present (FH).

ğ“œğ“ªğ“¤ğ“˜. â‰  Â»adverbÂ»in bulk (e.g., a purchase of fruit, coffee, or kerosene); wholesale, in large quantities, overall, undivided; by the yard (fabrics); in large pieces, not merely pieces of some item but the entire item (cooking); in its entirety, fully, whole, entire, completeÂ»(FH/pc). ğ“œğ“ªğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“œğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»I'm going to buy it [fabric] by the yard (rather than made up into articles such as shawls and blankets). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“œğ“ªğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»I'm going to cook some squash (by cutting whole squash up in big squares, laying skin side of each piece on bottom of pot for first layer, then skin upward for remaining layers, and cooking it outside on a fire with maple syrup and margarine). ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“œğ“ªğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“œğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»I'm going to buy the fruit in large quantities [not piece by piece]. ğ“œğ“ªğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜!Â»don't tell it all! ğ“²ğ“Ÿ. â‰  Â»posit positional article for standing inanimate singular nonsubject (also used for intangible entities: e.g., heart attack, song, pain). ğ“©ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“¡ğ“¶ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“˜Â»pass the water. ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“™ ğ“²ğ“ŸÂ»this coffee sitting [standing] here. ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“£ğ“©ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“ºğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜Â»I guess he will examine you now (literally, 'just now they'll examine your hurt, I suppose') (04/13/95/LS/pc:ok). ğ“¨ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¯ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“˜Â»let the feather touch it (literally, 'make the feather stand upright [and thereby touch it]'). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“¶ğ“Ÿ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“£ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“šÂ»turn that bread over (FH). ğ“ªğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜Â»look after the cooking (RBn3-26). ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¡ğ“¶ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ?Â»is the sun coming up? ğ“²ğ“Ÿ. â‰  Â»complementizerÂ»that, whatever, until (links a preceding subordinate clause to the following main clause).Â»ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“ºğ“˜ğ“©ğ“£ ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“Ÿ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“»ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜?Â»do you think you can do all of it? ğ“²ğ“Ÿ. â‰  evidential evidential marker indicating that speaker or addressee has circumstantial or sensory evidence (rather than witnessing) that the situation reported in the sentence occurred (can often be approximately translated as 'have/has/had already'). ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“Ÿ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“¡ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜Â»I had already left by the time he got there. ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¤'ğ“ª ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“£ ğ“²ğ“ŸÂ»that woman has fought; that woman did fight (FH:05/06/94). ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“£ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“œğ“˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»they had prepared it, and I'm eating it. ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“Ÿ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“¡ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ I had left when he got there. ğ“ªğ“µğ“£ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ?Â»is the car started? (FH:prod). ğ“ªğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“²ğ“ŸÂ»someone broke a window, that's the way it is (FH:01/07/95; LS:ok). ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“œğ“˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“®ğ“ŸÂ»you had cooked it and I'm eating it. ğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“œğ“£ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»I had already finished helping her when they got there (FH:prod). ğ“˜ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“¡ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜Â»you [singular] had already left when he got there (FH/07/27/95/pc:ok). ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“ºğ“˜ğ“©ğ“£ ğ“Ÿğ“²ğ“£ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ?Â»is everything there? (RBn12-11). ğ“ªğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“Ÿğ“²ğ“£ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ?Â»is there room over there? ğ“·ğ“£ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“¡ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“¡ğ“£ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ?Â»Sonny, has daylight come? ğ“µğ“šğ“¯ğ“Ÿ â‰  Â»(variants: ğ“µğ“šğ“¯ğ“Ÿ, ğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ, ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ). contÂ»continuative aspect postverbal marker (indicating ongoing action or state in present or past time) for moving 2nd singular subject (action or state may continue from past to present, corresponding to English perfect ['have/had been']).Â»['Moving' here means 'changing location'; motions or gestures that do not change the entity's location in horizontal space do not take this affix.] ğ“ªğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“šğ“¯ğ“Ÿ?Â»are you [moving, singular] looking for things? ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¯ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“ª ğ“µğ“šğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»you're pushing me. ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“¶ğ“Ÿ ğ“®ğ“¤ğ“¶ğ“Ÿ ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“šğ“¯ğ“Ÿ?Â»are you [moving, singular] going to cut the cake? ğ“µğ“£ğ“¡ğ“¶ğ“¡ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜Â»I heard you [moving, singular] were sick (03/09/95/MREI/pc:ok). ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“£Í˜ğ“Ÿ ğ“ªğ“·ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“šğ“¯ğ“Ÿ?Â»are you [moving, singular] going to be busy tomorrow? ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ â‰  Â»(variant of ğ“µğ“˜ğ“°ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ).

ğ“µğ“£ğ“§ğ“ªğ“²ğ“Ÿ. â‰  Â»verbÂ»[syncopatingÂ£?, _ğ“µğ“£ğ“§ğ“ªğ“²ğ“Ÿ?] (transitive) peel.Â»ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“ºğ“£ ğ“µğ“£ğ“§ğ“ªğ“²ğ“˜Â»peel the orange (RBn10-20).

ğ“µğ“£ğ“»ğ“ªğ“»ğ“£ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“µğ“¶ğ“»ğ“ªğ“»ğ“£, ğ“µğ“£ğ“»ğ“ªğ“»ğ“£, ğ“µğ“¶ğ“»ğ“ªğ“»ğ“£). verbÂ»[syncopatingÂ£, _ğ“µğ“£ğ“»ğ“ªğ“»ğ“£] (transitive) hurt or harm another physically, mistreat.Â»ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£ ğ“µğ“£ğ“»ğ“ªğ“»ğ“£ğ“¬ğ“£ ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»he [lying down] has really been hurt, they said (RB; FH). ğ“£ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£ ğ“µğ“£ğ“»ğ“ªğ“»ğ“£ğ“¬ğ“£ ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»he [sitting] is hurt [all beat up] (RB; FH). ğ“¯ğ“ğ“£ğ“»ğ“ªğ“»ğ“£Â»you caused suffering, you hurt him (FH). â€¢ harm another mentally, emotionally (e.g., by humiliating another or by dying).Â»ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¤'ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“Ÿ, ğ“µğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“£ğ“µğ“£ğ“»ğ“ªğ“»ğ“£Â»I pity you, your father hurt you [when he died] (uttered at a funeral) (RB). ğ“œğ“£ğ“»ğ“ªğ“»ğ“£Â»I caused suffering to him (e.g., by saying something harmful) (02/13/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.70).

Â»Ã°ikÅ¡Ä¯Ìce.Â»verbÂ»[syncopatingÂ£, _ğ“µğ“£ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ] (transitive) miss; fail at; be incorrect at, not get right (e.g., an action).Â»ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“œğ“£ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£Í˜ğ“²ğ“ŸÂ»I didn't tell it right (literally, 'telling it, I failed') (RBn23-17). â€¢ drop (e.g., an object or a comment into a conversation). ğ“œğ“£ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£Í˜ğ“²ğ“ŸÂ»I dropped it. ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£Í˜ğ“²ğ“ŸÂ»you dropped it (01/20/95/PM/pc:ok; BE2.35). â€¢ let slip (as a comment); let slip away (as when one takes one's eyes off a person for a minute and he/she is gone).

ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ â‰  Â»(variant: ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ). verbÂ»[stat., _ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ]Â»[possibly from ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜Â»'have'+ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ neg] (transitive) lack a thing, be devoid of, be lacking,Â»not have something any longer; have nothing.Â»ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ŸÂ»I lack it.Â»ğ“µğ“£ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ŸÂ»you lack it. ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ we lack it. ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ŸÂ»we [two or more] don't have any (#90/FH). ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ŸÂ»I have none (RBn3-39). ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“ºğ“Ÿğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ŸÂ»I don't have any money. ğ“·ğ“Ÿğ“µğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“ŸÂ»I have nothing to buy with (RBnB1-58). ğ“µğ“£ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ŸÂ»you have none. ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“ºğ“Ÿğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ŸÂ»I have no money (CQ ok; BE2.94). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜Â»there isn't any more (7/8/94/PM/#98b).

ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜ â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜). negÂ»[ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ŸÂ»negÂ»+ ğ“˜Â»imperative marker] don't!Â»ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“£ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜Â»don't do that (04/13/95/LS/pc:ok). ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜Â»don't say that (04/13/95/LS/pc:pl; RBn1-26). ğ“£ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜Â»don't laugh (04/13/95/LS/pc:ok [É£]). ğ“µğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜Â»don't buy it (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok). ğ“·ğ“Ÿğ“µğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜Â»don't sell it (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok). ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜Â»don't talk (04/26/95/LS/pc). ğ“£Í˜ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“£Í˜ ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜Â»don't talk English. ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜Â»don't move (01/20/95/ERE/pc:ok; 04/26/95/LS/pc:okc). ğ“¸ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜Â»don't cry (01/20/95/ERE/pc:ok). ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“©ğ“˜ ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“™Â»don't do that any more ('knock it off') (04/26/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.33).

ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ â‰  Â»(variant: ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ). verbÂ»[conjug. unknown] (intransitive) be none; beÂ»gone, absent, extinct, nonexistent, lacking.Â»ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ ğ“¬ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“Ÿ, ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ŸÂ»I went to the house, no one was there (BE2.157). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“·ğ“Ÿğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£ğ“Ÿ, ğ“£Í˜ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“ªğ“§ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ŸÂ»I can't see without my glasses (RB). Mary ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“£ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ, ğ“¬ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜Â»Mary was gone when I got there (FH/07/27/95/pc:prod). ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“£ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ, ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜Â»it was already gone when he came in (MSB). ğ“ºğ“˜ğ“©ğ“£ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ŸÂ»it's all gone (01/04/95/FH/pc). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“Ÿğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“£ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»the Osage language is all gone (01/06/95/FH/pc). ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Â»that house doesn't exist any more. ğ“ªğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“ªğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Â»the cook says there are no potatoes (RBnB1-43). â€¢ pass away, vanish.Â»ğ“¨ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“»ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜ ğ“µğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ ğ“¨ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“»ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“µğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“·ğ“£ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“¯ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¯ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“·ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»heaven and earth shall pass away but my word will endure (FH: from Matthew 24:35).â€¢Â»negÂ»not, not at all. ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²'ğ“Ÿğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ we don't kill at all.

ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜. â‰  Â»neg + potential markerÂ»won't. ğ“ªğ“¸ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“µğ“Ÿ [ğ“µ]ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“™Â»he won't lose it (literally, 'he will not be losing stuff'). ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“™Â»she won't go.

ğ“µğ“¶ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“¶ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“µğ“¶ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“£, ğ“µğ“¶ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“®ğ“¶). verbÂ»[syncopatingÂ£, _ğ“µğ“¶ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“¶] (transitive) clean up; cleanse; clean, disinfect (e.g., a buffalo hide)Â»(01/09/95/FH/pc:ok). ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“µğ“¶ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“¶ ğ“µğ“£Â»clean the house [singular addressee] (BE2.19). ğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ, ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£ğ“§ğ“˜Í˜, ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“¶ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“¶ğ“¬ğ“£ ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜Â»as you cleanse our hearts and minds. ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“£Í˜ ğ“¤ğ“ªğ“²ğ“£ ğ“¯ğ“ğ“¶ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“¶ ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“·ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“·ğ“ŸÂ»if you'll clean that oldtime blanket, I'll bind it (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod). ğ“œğ“¶ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“¶ ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“µğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“·ğ“˜Â»if I clean it, you bind it (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod).

ğ“µğ“¶ğ“¸ğ“ªÍ˜ â‰  Â»(variant of ğ“µğ“£ğ“¸ğ“ªÍ˜).

ğ“µğ“¶ğ“ºğ“Ÿ â‰  Â»(variants: ğ“µğ“¶ğ“ºğ“Ÿ, ğ“µğ“¶ğ“ºğ“£). verbÂ»[syncopatingÂ£, _ğ“µğ“¶ğ“ºğ“Ÿ] (transitive) select, choose; take; get; draw (water), gather or pick (e.g., fruit).Â»ğ“œğ“¶ğ“ºğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»I'm going to take it (03/07/95/FH/pc). ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“¡ğ“£Í˜ğ“¯ğ“ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“ªğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“¶ğ“ºğ“˜Â»help yourself to the peaches, take some peaches (03/07/95/FH/pc). ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ğ“¸ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“µğ“¶ğ“ºğ“˜Â»choose one (03/07/95/FH/pc; BE2.102). ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¸ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“ªğ“˜ ğ“µğ“¶ğ“ºğ“˜Â»get [take] some ice (01/31/95/FH/pc:okc). ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“·ğ“£ ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“ºğ“Ÿğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“œğ“¶ğ“ºğ“Ÿ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»I exchanged it, but I took money (1/20/83/631; 04/13/95/FH/pc:ok). ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“ºğ“£ ğ“ºğ“˜ğ“©ğ“£ ğ“µğ“¶ğ“ºğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»she took all the oranges, she's really stingy (04/26/95/FH/pc). ğ“©ğ“£ ğ“µğ“¶ğ“ºğ“˜Â»draw water (FH; ok). ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“£ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“·ğ“£ğ“œğ“¶ğ“ºğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»I'll take your word for it (FH). ğ“µğ“¶ğ“ºğ“˜Â»take it away (FH/09/23/01/pc:prod). ğ“»ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¸ğ“Ÿ ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“µğ“¶ğ“ºğ“™ ğ“²'ğ“Ÿğ“µğ“˜ ğ“¸ğ“²ğ“£Â»take a stick and just almost kill someone (FH:prod).

ğ“µğ“¶ğ“»ğ“˜ â‰  Â»(variants: ğ“µğ“¶ğ“»ğ“˜ğ“·ğ“˜, ğ“µğ“¶ğ“»ğ“˜Í˜). verbÂ»[syncopatingÂ£, _ğ“µğ“¶ğ“»ğ“˜] (transitive) wash (e.g., dishes, parts of the body, food items, a car)Â»(03/16/95/JS/pc; FH:3/21/96). ğ“¯ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“¶ğ“»ğ“˜ ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“œğ“˜Â»I want to wash my hands (03/16/95/JS/pc:okc). ğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“™ ğ“µğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“™ ğ“¡ğ“£Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“œğ“¶ğ“»ğ“˜Â»I washed dishes twice today (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). ğ“¡ğ“£Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“œğ“¶ğ“»ğ“˜Â»I washed dishes, too (RBn3-15). ğ“ªğ“µğ“£ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“·ğ“£ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“¶ğ“¡ğ“¶ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“¡ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“¯ğ“ğ“¶ğ“»ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ?Â»my car is dirty, could you wash it this evening? ğ“Ÿğ“²ğ“£. â‰  Â»conjunctionÂ»and (in numbers only), plus.Â»ğ“§ğ“Ÿğ“œğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¡ğ“¶ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“µğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“Ÿğ“²ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ğ“¸ğ“²ğ“£Â»two hundred and one (04/11/95/LS/pc:ok). ğ“§ğ“Ÿğ“œğ“˜Í˜ ğ“µğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“Ÿğ“²ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ğ“¸ğ“²ğ“£Â»twenty-one (literally, 'twenty and one') (05/02/95/LS/pc). ğ“Ÿğ“²ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ğ“¸ğ“²ğ“£Â»plus one.

ğ“Ÿğ“°ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“Ÿğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜, ğ“Ÿğ“°ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜). conjunctionÂ»that is why, therefore, thus, soÂ»(FHt#128). ğ“ªğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ğ“¸ğ“Ÿ ğ“¬ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“Ÿğ“°ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“ŸÂ»I went riding and that is why I'm tired (LH 07/18/96:tape). ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“ºğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“œğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“¶ ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ ğ“Ÿğ“°ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜ ğ“œğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜Â»they usually put oranges on the table, that's the reason I bought some (FHt#128). ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™, ğ“Ÿğ“°ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¤'ğ“Ÿğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜Â»don't pity him because he did it himself (FHt#128). ğ“¡ğ“ªğ“œğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“£Í˜, ğ“Ÿğ“°ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¡ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“œğ“¶ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“¶ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“©ğ“£Í˜ ğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“¶ ğ“°ğ“˜Â»I'm going to cook beans tomorrow, therefore tonight I'll clean them and put them in water.

ğ“Ÿğ“°ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“Ÿğ“°ğ“¸ğ“˜, ğ“Ÿğ“°ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜, ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜). verbÂ»[uninflected] (intransitive)Â»it is time.Â»ğ“µğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ ğ“Ÿğ“°ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»it's almost time (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“µğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¡ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“Ÿğ“°ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»it's almost time to dance (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok). ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“ªğ“»ğ“¶ ğ“Ÿğ“°ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»it's time to plant corn (03/22/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.141). â€¢Â»noun Â»time, the moment for somethingÂ»ğ“ªğ“©ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜, ğ“Ÿğ“°ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»hurry up, it is time (literally, 'hurry, the time has arrived') (03/22/95/FH/pc:ok; 03/22/95/FH/pc). â€¢Â»adverbÂ»when (literally, 'at the time that').Â»â€¢Â»pronÂ»that (standing animate).

Â»ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“»ğ“˜ğ“¨ğ“£Â»I think it's right (PM). ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“»ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£Â»you think it's right (PM; RBn1-40). ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»you said it right (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). â€¢Â»conjunctionÂ»thus, therefore.Â»ğ“œğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“œğ“˜ ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“Ÿğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜Í˜Â»I made him a proposition (literally, 'I wanted to buy it, therefore I raised something'). â€¢Â»verbÂ»[uninflected] (intransitive) mean, signify.Â»Â»ğ“Ÿğ“ğ“ªÃ½ğ“£ ğ“¨ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“ª ğ“©ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“£ ğ“£ğ“Ÿ 'ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜' ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»Echogee in the Creek language means 'little deer'. â€¢Â»happen, be so.Â»ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»anyway it's never going to happen (literally, 'anyway, it will not be so') (04/17/95/LS/pc:okc; RBn1-MOJ/p28). â€¢Â»(be) as .Â».Â». as.Â»ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¸ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“ªğ“¡ğ“ª ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»he was as blue as the sky (RBn15-01).

ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ. â‰  Â»verb phraseÂ»[syncopatingÂ£, ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ _ğ“µğ“˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ] say something right or correctly.Â»ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“ŸÂ»you said it right; you named it right (RBn10-6:JW).

ğ“²ğ“¶ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“²ğ“¶ğ“¤ğ“˜).Â»noun Â»spoon (Osage spoons were originally clamshells from creeks, used only for scraping corn, with little ones for children, larger ones for adults; this term is now used for spoons of other materials such as metal, plastic, or wood) (03/14/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.126); abalone shell; shovel (03/09/95/FH/pc; unconfirmed as 'shovel'). ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“²ğ“¶ğ“¤ğ“ŸÂ»that spoon (03/14/95/FH/pc:hc). ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“ºğ“Ÿ ğ“²ğ“¶ğ“¤ğ“ŸÂ»metal spoon. ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“£ ğ“²ğ“¶ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“²ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“£Â»eat soup with a spoon [to plural addressee].

ğ“¡ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“¶ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ â‰  .Â»noun Â»name of a dance (literally, 'crooked horns') received by Poncas before they had horses, when dogs carried their loads. [The dance was given by the Poncas to the Kaws; subsequently the Kaws gave their drum to Pawhuska and Hominy Osages; the drum was given by Poncas to Grayhorse Osages (RBn11-01/JW&FW; HHsk/c.1977).]

ğ“°ğ“˜ â‰  (variant ofÂ»ğ“£ğ“°ğ“˜).

ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜. â‰  Â»potentialÂ»marker+contÂ»irrealis or potential: be it (the case that), if (it is the case that), it will be the case that, in the event that, it may be that; would that.Â»[Note that 3rd person continuative ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Â»is used even with 1st or 2nd person subjects in clauses of this type.] ğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“œğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜, ğ“ªğ“˜ğ“©ğ“£ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»[but] if I go I won't be afraid. ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¤'ğ“¶ğ“Ÿ ğ“¯ğ“ª ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“Ÿ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“Ÿğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“£ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»I'm going to keep on [trying] until I learn the Osage language (RBn10-10:JW). ğ“œğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜, ğ“·ğ“£ğ“¤'ğ“¶ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»if I buy it, I'll give it to you. ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“« ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»you're always going to go to dances (MSB-9-3-82). ğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“ªğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“šğ“¤ğ“£ ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ğ“·ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¤ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“œğ“£Í˜ğ“œğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™ ğ“¯ğ“£ ğ“Ÿğ“»ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“¬ğ“£ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“·ğ“£ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»on Saturday what if I take him to town and trade him for another one that knows how to work (cf. ğ“˜ğ“œğ“£Í˜ğ“œğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™ 'what if I take him') (RBn10-2:MOJ/79; ğ“£ğ“¡ğ“¶ğ“¡ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“˜ â‰  (variant: ğ“£ğ“¡ğ“¶ğ“¡ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“˜).Â»verbÂ»[uninflected] (transitive?)Â»be sick or have health trouble with (an ailing part of the body or some other condition). ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“¤'ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“ºğ“Ÿ ğ“£ğ“¡ğ“¶ğ“¡ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»my sister-in-law is sick with her stomach, they say (FH/09/23/01/pc:prod). ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“ºğ“Ÿ ğ“£ğ“¡ğ“¶ğ“¡ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»he [lying down] is sick of [i.e., 'to, in'] his stomach (FH/09/23/01/pc). ğ“¯ğ“¶ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ ğ“£ğ“¡ğ“¶ğ“¡ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»he [lying down] has intestinal trouble, they said (12/30/94/FH/pc: lying down; FH/09/23/01/pc; BE2.1). ğ“¯ğ“¶ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ ğ“£ğ“¡ğ“¶ğ“¡ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“ŸÂ»I've had intestinal trouble.

ğ“£ğ“œğ“˜Í˜ â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“£ğ“œğ“˜). v [stat., ğ“£_ğ“œğ“˜Í˜] [doubly stative (semantic subject and object both use patient pronominals); 2nd person either stative or active] (transitive)Â»have enough of, get enough of, have one's fill of, be sated withÂ»(either a positive or negative thing); be satiatedÂ»with; beÂ»tired of, be negatively affected by too much of something (02/03/95/FH/pc:ok). ğ“˜Í˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“œğ“˜Â»I've had enough of it. ğ“£ğ“µğ“£ğ“œğ“˜Â»you've had enough of it. ğ“˜Í˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“œğ“˜Â»we've have enough of it. ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“¬ğ“š ğ“£Í˜ğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“œğ“˜Í˜, ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ ğ“£Í˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“œğ“˜Â»I've had enough of being pitiful (12/30/94/FH/pc). ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“œğ“˜Í˜, ğ“£ğ“µğ“£ğ“œğ“˜Í˜Â»you've had enough. ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“·ğ“Ÿğ“œğ“˜Í˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»we're tired of them; we've had enough of them (FH:10/12/95; RBn1-MOJ/p56). ğ“£ğ“·ğ“£ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“œğ“˜Â»I've had enough of you [from ğ“£-ğ“·ğ“£-ğ“˜Í˜-ğ“œğ“˜Í˜]. ğ“·ğ“Ÿğ“œğ“˜Í˜ ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»we [two] had enough (MSB). ğ“£ğ“œğ“˜ ğ“¸ğ“²ğ“£Í˜Â»have more than one's fill (especially more than one's share of pain and suffering) (03/08/95/FH/pc:ok). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ ğ“£Í˜ğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“œğ“˜Â»I'm pitiful with suffering [ğ“£Í˜ğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“œğ“˜Í˜Â»from ğ“£-ğ“˜Í˜-ğ“œğ“˜Í˜] (RBn1-56; (FH/09/23/01/pc: prod). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“œğ“˜ ğ“¸ğ“²ğ“£Í˜Â»I'm pitiful with suffering (RBn1-56; FH/09/23/01/pc: ok).

ğ“£ğ“œğ“˜Í˜ğ“¸ğ“²ğ“£Í˜. â‰  verbÂ»[stat., ğ“£_ğ“œğ“˜Í˜ğ“¸ğ“²ğ“£Í˜] (transitive)Â»have more than enough of, have more than one's fill or share of (e.g., sorrow to the point of being pitiful, excessive woe). ğ“£ğ“œğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“²ğ“£Â»to have had more than one's share [e.g., of pain] or more than one can bear (RBn1-MOJ/p56; BE2.61; 12/30/94/FH/pc/ok). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ ğ“£ğ“œğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“²ğ“£Â»pitiful with suffering (RBn1-MOJ/p56).

ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“™ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“˜, ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“Ÿ, ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“™). verb, ğ“˜ğ“°jğ“Ÿğ“²ğ“°ğ“£vğ“ŸÂ»[uninflected] (intransitive)Â»(be) ashamed, feel ashamedÂ»(04/20/95/LS/pc). ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“ğ“Ÿ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»I'm ashamed (04/20/95/LS/pc). ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¡ğ“Ÿ I'm ashamed.Â»ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“™ ğ“µğ“šğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»you're shameful (9/17/94/FH/pc). ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“™ ğ“µğ“ŸÂ»you should be ashamed (literally, 'that makes one feel ashamed') (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77; CQc). ğ“¯ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“™ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜Â»he's ashamed of himself (RBn10-21/JW&FW/77).

ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“™ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“˜, ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“˜, ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“˜; [Hominy dialect]Â»Ã­iÅ¡Äewai, iiÅ¡ÄÃ©wai). verb, ğ“˜ğ“°jğ“Ÿğ“²ğ“°ğ“£vğ“ŸÂ»[regularÂ£-ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜, ğ“£_ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“™Â»(often uninflected)] (intransitive)Â»dress up in one's best attire, get dolled up or dressed up; (be) dolled up or dressed upÂ»(04/26/95/LS/pc:okc). ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ â‰  (variant of ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£).

(literally, 'a lie!') (FH 2-24-83; MSB). ğ“£ğ“¸ğ“ªğ“¬ğ“Ÿğ“¯ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜Â»one who always lies; a liar (02/15/95/FH/pc:prod).

ğ“£Í˜ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ ğ“²'ğ“ªğ“¤ğ“˜ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“£Í˜ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“²'ğ“ªğ“¤ğ“˜, ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ ğ“²'ğ“ªğ“¤ğ“˜, ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“²'ğ“ªğ“¤ğ“˜). verb phraseÂ»[stat., ğ“£Í˜ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ _ğ“²'ğ“ªğ“¤ğ“˜] be sleepy (literally, 'eyelids droop'). ğ“ªğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ğ“¸ğ“Ÿ ğ“¬ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“Ÿ, ğ“Ÿğ“°ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜ ğ“£Í˜ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“²'ğ“ªğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»I went riding and that is why I'm sleepy (03/10/95/MREI/pc:ok; BE2.123). ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“£Í˜ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ ğ“²'ğ“ªğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»he was tired and sleepy (MREI: ğ“£Í˜ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“²'ğ“ªğ“¤ğ“˜Â»or ğ“£Í˜ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ ğ“²'ğ“ªğ“¤ğ“˜, same).

ğ“£Í˜ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“£Í˜ â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“£). noun Â»[ğ“£Í˜ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“˜ + ğ“¡ğ“£Í˜] eyebrows.

ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ â‰  Â»pronpÂ»[ğ“¤ğ“˜Â»pron + ğ“²ğ“ŸÂ»posit] this (standing; a default combination of demonstrative and positional article used for both concrete and abstract items).Â»ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“ªÍ˜?Â»what kind of song is that? ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“Ÿ. â‰  Â»pronp [ğ“¤ğ“˜ pron + ğ“²ğ“ŸÂ»positÂ»+ ğ“µğ“ŸÂ»pron] group of inanimate items sitting there.Â»['Standing' positional article ğ“²ğ“ŸÂ»pluralizes 'sitting' entities.] ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“ŸÂ»there's something sitting there; there it sits (FH).

ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“Ÿğ“µğ“Ÿ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“£ğ“µğ“Ÿ, ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“Ÿ). interjectionÂ»good-bye, farewell (more literally, 'that's all', 'it's over with'; to a dead person)Â»(BE2.59; FH/11/19/01/tape); exclamation acknowledging the end of earthly living, the final event in lifeÂ»(HH; BE2.59). ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ â‰  . noun Â»bit, portion (of any item); twelve and a half cents.

ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¬ğ“Ÿğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜). noun [ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»+ ğ“µğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜] quarter (25-cent coin; literally, 'two bits') (04/11/95/LS/pc:okc; t14a-p1b/14, t44). ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¬ğ“Ÿğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™ it will be a quarter (literally, 'it will be two bits' [noun is used as verb]; a phrase said by seller to ask for his money) (BE2.110). ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¬ğ“Ÿğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“ªğ“§ğ“˜Í˜Â»put your 25 cents in.

ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¶ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ. â‰  Â»v [regularÂ£ ğ“¤ğ“˜-del., _(ğ“¤ğ“˜)ğ“¯ğ“¶ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ] (transitive) pay (a debt), pay for (a purchase).Â»[Used to describe the ceremony of paying for the drum at the Osage War Dances.] ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¶ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»I paid for it.Â»ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¶ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»you paid for it. ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¶ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ she paid for it. ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¶ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»we [plural] paid for it. ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¶ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»I'll pay for it (FH:prod, 2/97). ğ“·ğ“Ÿğ“¶ğ“ºğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¶ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»I'm going to pay this big debt (03/06/95/FH/pc:prod). ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¶ğ“¬ğ“Ÿğ“¬ğ“£ ğ“©ğ“˜Â»he paid me for it (MSB). ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¶ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ ğ“©ğ“˜Â»you paid me for it. ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¶ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“£!Â»pay for it [plural addressee]!

ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“¸ğ“˜, ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“¸ğ“˜, ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜). adv, n while, meanwhile, awhile, for a while, after a while, a little while. ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“¸ğ“˜! stop! wait! ğ“¤ğ“£-. â‰  Â»prefixÂ»(dative prefix, indicating that an action is done in the presence of someone [e.g., ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“£ğ“ŸÂ»'speak in the presence of someone'], for the benefit of someone ["benefactive"], in place of someone, or to someone else's possession; can also indicate action transferring something to someone).Â»[Dative ğ“¤ğ“£-Â»is omitted after pronominal prefixes (ğ“¤ğ“£-del.) in most but not all verbs. ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜). adjectiveÂ»each.Â»ğ“¡ğ“ªğ“¸ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ ğ“©ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»each person, everyone has this sickness (01/20/95/PM/pc). ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“£Í˜ ğ“µğ“Ÿ, ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“œğ“˜Â»I want each of them to have this blanket for his/her own; they can all call it theirs, as each one has a part in this blanket (01/20/95/PM/pc:prod orig; BE2.38; RBn1-MOJ/p52b).

ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜). verbÂ»[regularÂ£ ğ“¤ğ“£-del., _(ğ“¤ğ“£)ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜] (intransitive) be apart, separated, divorced, divided, distant, or estranged from each other (e.g., an estranged married couple, egg yolks separated from whites).Â»ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“™Â»they're separated [by physical distance] (02/22/95/FH/pc:prod orig; 04/14/95/PM/pc:ok). ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜Â»they are separated from one another [as in a divorce], they're divided (01/20/95/PM/pc:ok). â€¢Â»(transitive)Â»divide or separate the parts of something; separate from, divorce, or become estranged from.Â»ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“ŸÂ»I'm dividing the egg yolk from the white (literally, 'I'm separating the egg') (04/14/95/PM/pc:ok). ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»I'm going to quit him/jump from him (04/14/95/PM/pc:prod). ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜Â»I divorce him.Â»ğ“µğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜Â»you divorce him.Â»ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜Â»he divorces her.Â»ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜Â»we divorce.

ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜ â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜). verbÂ»[stat. ğ“¤ğ“£-del., _ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜] (intransitive)Â»beÂ»glad, feel good (also used as an equivalent of 'thank you').Â»ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜ I'm glad.Â»ğ“µğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜Â»you're glad.Â»ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜Â»she's glad. ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜(?)Â»we're glad. ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜Â»I feel good, I'm glad, I like it, thank you (02/01/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.59). â€¢Â»(transitive)Â»like, love, enjoy, be happy about, be pleased with.Â»ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜Â»when you cook, I like it (RBn; MREI/01/11/93). ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“ºğ“¶ ğ“»ğ“¶ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜Â»I like red grapes (02/03/95/FH/pc:okc). ğ“»ğ“˜Í˜ğ“©ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜Â»he likes candy (02/16/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.79). ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»she likes to eat meat (FH). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»he likes to drink (02/16/95/FH/pc:ok). ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜ ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»the children enjoy it. ğ“»ğ“˜Í˜ğ“©ğ“£ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜Â»I enjoy eating candy (3-10-83-A; 01/04/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.64).

ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“Ÿ â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“Ÿ). cau [regularÂ£ ğ“¤ğ“£-ret., _ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“Ÿ] [ğ“¤ğ“£-Â»datÂ»or ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¤-Â»suu + ğ“µğ“ŸÂ»cau] (transitive)Â»make or have someone engage voluntarily in some act; let or allow someone to do somethingÂ»ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“£Í˜ ğ“£Í˜ ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»he had his children wear their blankets. ğ“£Í˜ğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“¯ğ“£Í˜ğ“°ğ“ªğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“¡ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ ğ“¤ğ“£[ğ“µ]ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»the mother had the child take a bath.

ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“£ğ“¸ğ“ªÍ˜. â‰  Â»verbÂ»[stat. ğ“¤ğ“£-del., _(ğ“¤ğ“£)ğ“µğ“£ğ“¸ğ“ªÍ˜] [ğ“¤ğ“£-Â»dat + ğ“µğ“£ğ“¸ğ“ªÍ˜] (transitive)Â»break off or break someone's (e.g., body part).Â»ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“£ğ“µğ“£ğ“¸ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»they broke your arm. ğ“˜ ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“£ğ“¸ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»they broke his arm. ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“£ğ“¸ğ“ªÍ˜ they broke my.Â»ğ“µğ“£ğ“µğ“£ğ“¸ğ“ªÍ˜ they broke your.Â»ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“£ğ“¸ğ“ªÍ˜ they broke his. ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£ğ“¸ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ they broke our. ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£ğ“¸ğ“ªÍ˜ they broke their.

ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“¶ğ“ºğ“Ÿ. â‰  verbÂ»[syncopatingÂ£ ğ“¤ğ“£-del., (ğ“¤ğ“£)_ğ“µğ“¶ğ“ºğ“Ÿ] [ğ“¤ğ“£-Â»datÂ»+ ğ“µğ“¶ğ“ºğ“Ÿ] take away from someoneÂ»ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“¶ğ“ºğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜Â»go take it away from him (03/16/95/JS/pc). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“¶ğ“ºğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“©ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ?Â»are you going to take pennies/change away from me? (03/15/95/PM/pc:okc; LS ok; BE2.131). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¬ğ“£ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“¶ğ“ºğ“ŸÂ»God takes away bad things from me (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¬ğ“£ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“¶ğ“ºğ“ŸÂ»God takes away bad things [from us, from them] (FH/09/23/01/pc). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“Ÿğ“¡ğ“Ÿ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“®ğ“£ğ“®ğ“£ ğ“©ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ, ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¬ğ“£ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“¶ğ“ºğ“™Â»I am weak but thou art strong, Jesus keep me from all wrong (MJ partial version of the Christian hymn "I Am Weak But Thou Art Strong"). ğ“µğ“£ğ“µğ“¶ğ“ºğ“ŸÂ»they took something away from you (03/16/95/JS/pc:ok). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“µğ“£ğ“µğ“¶ğ“ºğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“™Â»they are going to take pennies away from you (03/15/95/PM/pc:ok; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok).

ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜. â‰  Â»verbÂ»[regularÂ£ ğ“¤ğ“£-del.+syncopatingÂ£, _(ğ“¤ğ“£)_ğ“µğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜] [ğ“¤ğ“£-Â»datÂ»+ ğ“µğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜] (transitive)Â»buy for someone, buy in someone's place for the benefit of a third person.Â»ğ“˜ğ“œğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜Â»I bought it for him. ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜Â»you bought it for him. ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜Â»she bought it for him. ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“ªğ“˜ ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜Â»she's buying him some apples. ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜Â»they bought it for him. ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜Â»we bought it for him. ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“ªğ“˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜Â»buy me some apples [for him or her].

ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¤- â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¡-, ğ“¤ğ“£-). prefix one's own (suus prefix: object belongs to or is related to the subject).Â»[ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¤-Â»becomes ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¡-Â»before ğ“², ğ“¤, ğ“¬, ğ“°;Â»while ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¤-ğ“µ simplifies to ğ“¤ğ“µ and becomes ğ“§ (e.g., ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¤- + ğ“µğ“¶ğ“»ğ“˜ 'wash' becomes ğ“§ğ“¶ğ“»ğ“˜Â»'wash one's own'); otherwise, ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¤-Â»becomes simple ğ“¤ğ“£-.] ğ“»ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“§ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“šğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»you are with him [family]. ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¡ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“ªğ“¸ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™ grğ“˜ğ“©ğ“°ğ“²ğ“£ğ“§ğ“°rğ“Ÿğ“© he's making his grandchildren special.

ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“Ÿ. â‰  Â»verb phraseÂ»[regularÂ£ ğ“¤ğ“£-ret.+syncopatingÂ£ ğ“¤â‰¥ğ“¬, _ğ“¤ğ“£_ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“Ÿ] [ğ“¤ğ“£-Â»datÂ»+ ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“Ÿ]Â»(transitive) make or produce for s.o. ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¸ğ“ªÍ˜. â‰  Â»verbÂ»[stat. ğ“¤ğ“£-del., _(ğ“¤ğ“£)ğ“¸ğ“ªÍ˜]Â»[ğ“¤ğ“£-Â»datÂ»+ ğ“¸ğ“ªÍ˜] something belonging to one breaks.Â»[Possessor of the broken thing is expressed by patient pronominal prefixes.] ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¸ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»something of mine broke (MRB 2-24-83). ğ“µğ“£ğ“¸ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»something of yours broke. ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¸ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»something of his broke.

ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“ºğ“ª. â‰  Â»verb, adjectiveÂ»[stat. ğ“¤ğ“£-del., _(ğ“¤ğ“£)ğ“ºğ“ª] (transitive)Â»enjoy, like, (be) happy or glad about somethingÂ»(12/30/94/FH/pc). ğ“˜Í˜ğ“ºğ“ªÂ»I enjoy it.Â»ğ“µğ“£ğ“ºğ“ªÂ»you enjoy it.Â»ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“ºğ“ªÂ»she enjoys it.Â»ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“ºğ“ª, ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“ºğ“ªÍ˜Â»we enjoy it.Â»ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“ºğ“ª, ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“ºğ“ª, ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“ºğ“ªÍ˜ they enjoy it [all three forms are correct and synonymous]. ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“ºğ“ªÂ»when you cook I enjoy it (RBn; MREI/01/11/93?). ğ“µğ“£ğ“ºğ“ªğ“»ğ“£ ğ“¸ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“©ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ, ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜?Â»you look very unhappy, what is it? ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“µğ“Ÿ â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“Ÿ). cau [regularÂ£ _ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“µğ“Ÿ] [ğ“¤ğ“£-Â»datÂ»+ ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“µğ“Ÿ] (transitive)Â»let or allow someone to do somethingÂ»ğ“Ÿ ğ“ªğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“ŸÂ»let her help (FH). ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“ªğ“²ğ“£ğ“²ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“™ ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“Ÿ ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜Â»don't let him go on and on [talking] (MSB:t9). â€¢Â»have someone do something for his/her own benefit.Â»ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“£Í˜ ğ“£Í˜ ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“ŸÂ»have him wear a blanket. ğ“¡ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“ŸÂ»you had me bathe (MREI). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“Ÿğ“ºğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“ŸÂ»mail this letter to her ['to her' implied by ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“Ÿ] (02/15/95/FH/pc:okc). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“ºğ“ªğ“Ÿ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“™Â»we're going to show them a good time.

ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“¸ğ“Ÿ. â‰  Â»verbÂ»[regularÂ£ _ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“¸ğ“Ÿ] [presumably ğ“¤ğ“£-Â»datÂ»+ ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“Ÿ] (transitive)Â»make or prepare for someone (e.g., prepare a bed, clothing, or food). ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“ªğ“§ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“°ğ“ªğ“˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“¸ğ“˜Â»make me some sandwiches (RBn10-2). ğ“®ğ“£ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“·ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“¸ğ“ŸÂ»I made a meat pie for you (MREI 11-1-83-8). ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ. â‰  Â»contÂ»continuative aspect postverbal marker (indicating ongoing action or state in present, past, or future time) for 1st singular sitting or lying down subject.Â»[ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»is sometimes used for 1st singular subjects that are not lying down; hence it can be regarded as the default 1st singular continuative marker.] ğ“µğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»I'm here (FH). ğ“œğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»I'm going; I will go. ğ“ªğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»I was cooking; I am cooking. ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»I'm just sitting here [near you]. ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“Ÿğ“»ğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“·ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¸ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»I have lost my handkerchief (04/11/95/LS/pc:ok; BE2.63; 04/11/95/LS/pc:okc) [contrast this example with ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“Ÿğ“»ğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“·ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¸ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“µğ“ŸÂ»'I lost my handkerchief' (04/11/95/LS/pc:ok)]. ğ“»ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“¸ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»my leg is broken (FH). ğ“·ğ“Ÿğ“œğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»I'm selling it [contrast this example with ğ“·ğ“Ÿğ“œğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜Â»'I sold it'].

ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ â‰  (variant: ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜). noun [ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜Â»+ ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜] mule, jack mule, donkey, burro, ass (literally, 'big ears')Â»(02/27/95/FH/pc:ok, prod; 01/20/95/PM/pc:prod). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“¬ğ“š ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“™, ğ“ªğ“¤'ğ“¶ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“¶ğ“²'ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“ªğ“µğ“¶ğ“²'ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“·ğ“£Í˜Â»we're too poor to feed that lazy donkey (literally, 'we are poor, that donkey who was lazy, we couldn't feed him') (RBn10-2:MOJ/79).

ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“©ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜, ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜). verbÂ»[regularÂ£, _ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜] (transitive)Â»hear, hear about, understandÂ»(RBn10-5:MOJ/79). ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜, ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜Â»I heard it.Â»ğ“µğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜, ğ“µğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜Â»you heard it.Â»ğ“˜Í˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»we heard it. ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜Â»I heard it myself (01/04/95/FH/pc). ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜Â»I hear it [with contrastive emphasis on "I"] (05/01/95/LS/pc). ğ“µğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤'ğ“ªÍ˜?Â»have you heard about it? did you hear about it? ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“§ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ â‰  Â»(variant: ğ“©ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¡ğ“˜). adj,Â»verbÂ»[regularÂ£, _ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“§ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¡ğ“˜] (intransitive)Â»(be) sneaky, hide, be sly, secretly scheme against someone, go behind someone's back, be cunning (as Coyote is in stories);Â»(transitive)Â»hide, conceal.Â»ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“·ğ“£ğ“œğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜, ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“§ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¡ğ“˜Â»I bought something for you and I've hidden it (FH). ğ“µğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“§ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¡ğ“˜Â»did you hide it? ğ“ªğ“²ğ“£ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“ªğ“²ğ“£, ğ“ªğ“²ğ“£ğ“Ÿ). adj,Â»verbÂ»[stat., ğ“ª_ğ“²ğ“£]Â»(be) plentiful, many, abound, exist in large quantity, (be) a lot of, (be) full of (e.g., worms).Â»ğ“¡ğ“¶ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£ ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“·ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“£Â»I've got a lot to do (literally, 'many chores abound for me') (RBn12-07; FH/11/19/01/pc: okc). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£ ğ“ªğ“·ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“ªğ“µğ“£ğ“²ğ“£Â»you're really busy (04/25/95/PM/pc:prod). ğ“ªğ“·ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“ªğ“µğ“£ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ ğ“£ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜Â»I know you have had a lot to do (RBn10-4:MOJ/79). ğ“¨ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“»ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“µğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜ ğ“ªğ“²ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜, ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“œğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜Â»if there are such beautiful things [abounding] in the world, I ought to go see them. ğ“·ğ“Ÿğ“²'ğ“˜ ğ“ªğ“²ğ“£ğ“ŸÂ»there are lots of snakes (RBn3-09). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“°ğ“ªğ“Ÿ ğ“ªğ“²ğ“£Â»there are a lot of pecans (RBn10-2; LS:ok). ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“ªğ“²ğ“£Â»a lot of kids (LS). ğ“ªğ“©ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“œğ“Ÿ ğ“ªğ“²ğ“£Â»a lot of food (04/17/95/LS/pc:ok). ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“£Í˜ ğ“ªğ“²ğ“£Â»a lot of blankets (LS). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£ğ“§ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“ªğ“²ğ“£ğ“ŸÂ»smart (literally, 'mind plentiful') (04/17/95/LS/pc:ok; MJ/11/19/83). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£ğ“§ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“ªğ“²ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»he has a lot on his mind (EREsr). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“¶ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“ªğ“²ğ“£Â»wormy, full of worms. â€¢Â»(be)Â»excessive orÂ»theÂ»most extreme, worst or best (above all others in a certain aspect).Â»ğ“£ğ“¸ğ“ªğ“¬ğ“Ÿğ“¯ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“ªğ“²ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Â»he's standing on top of all the liars; he's the worst of the liars (literally, 'he is extreme in lying constantly') (RBn12-10/MJ; CQc).

Mary ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“¯ğ“£Â»Mary is worried about something. ğ“ªğ“µğ“£ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“¯ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»he's worried about his car. ğ“»ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“™Â»Little-legs is worried about us (RBn23-17). ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“šğ“¯ğ“£Â»ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“™Â»we're anxious [note unexpected ğ“£Â»before ğ“¯ğ“£Â»in ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“šğ“¯ğ“£] (LS:prod). â€¢Â»focus on, pay attention to, look into, attend to, think aboutÂ»(FH:5/01/96/tape; 03/24/95/PM/pc:okc). ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ ğ“¡ğ“˜Â»I haven't thought about it [expected Mod. Os.)] (03/24/95/PM/pc:prod). ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“¯ğ“£Â»pay attention to the children (05/01/95/LS/pc; 01/04/95/FH/pc/ok). ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“£Â»pay attention to the children (FH/09/25/01/prod; BE2.2; 03/24/95/PM/pc:ok). ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“¯ğ“£ ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜, ğ“ªğ“§ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Â»don't pay any attention to him, he's mad (RBn11-01/JW&FW&HHask).

ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“¯ğ“£ ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ â‰  Â»(variant: ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“¯ğ“£ ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ). verb phraseÂ»[conjug. unknown (presumably stat., ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“¯ğ“£ _ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ)] (transitive)Â»disuse, be unconcerned with, disregard, not pay attention to (literally, 'not worried about')Â»(05/01/95/LS/pc:ok: disregard). ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“¯ğ“£ ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜Â»don't pay any attention to him (RBn11-01/JW&FW&HHsk/c.1976). â€¢ (intransitive)Â»beÂ»unobserved, as a customÂ»(FH/09/25/01/ok).

ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£, ğ“ªğ“§ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£, ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£, ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£). adverbÂ»in spite of everything, inevitably, contrarily, anyhow, anyway, even so, regardless, notwithstanding everything, however, nevertheless, at any rateÂ»(RBn1-MOJ/p28b; 02/01/95/FH/pc:okc; 05/01/95/LS/pc:ok). ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“ŸÂ»it's that way anyway (FH). ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“©ğ“£ğ“»ğ“¶ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Â»in spite of everything it's raining (05/01/95/LS/pc). ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“™Â»in spite of it, they're dancing (05/01/95/LS/pc). ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“©ğ“£ğ“»ğ“¶ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“™Â»in spite of the fact it's raining, they're dancing (05/01/95/LS/pc). ğ“ªğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“šğ“¤ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»Useless couldn't help but dance (literally, 'Useless danced anyway') (RBn10-2:MOJ/79). â€¢Â»v (intransitive) [uninflected] get it, do it or make it despite something, have one's way.Â»ğ“£ğ“µğ“˜ğ“»ğ“ªğ“¯ğ“£ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»I said no, but he's going to have his way (FH/11/19/01/pc:prod).

(01/12/95/FH/pc:okc). ğ“°ğ“ªğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“ŸÂ»I am cooking four (01/12/95/FH/pc:ok). ğ“®ğ“¶ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“£ ğ“ªğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜ ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“£ ğ“²ğ“ŸÂ»they cooked the turkey soup well (literally, 'cooking the turkey soup they did it well') (01/12/95/FH/pc:okc). ğ“ªğ“©ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“œğ“Ÿ ğ“¡ğ“¶ğ“¤ğ“« ğ“ªğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“£ ğ“²ğ“ŸÂ»they cooked many foods, a lot of food (01/12/95/FH/pc:ok, prod). ğ“ªğ“©ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“œğ“Ÿ ğ“ªğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜ ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“£ğ“²ğ“ŸÂ»the food was cooked well (literally, 'cooking the food, they did it well'). ğ“ªğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“¬ğ“£ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»she is a good cook (literally, 'she knows how to cook') (01/14/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.23). ğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“™Â»I cooked it. ğ“ªğ“µğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“™Â»you cooked it (MSB 2-24-83). ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ªğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜ [ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µ] ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»we [two] cooked it. ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ªğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»we [plural] cooked it. ğ“°ğ“ªğ“»ğ“¶ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ªğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“™Â»we [plural] are going to cook some meat.

ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜Í˜, ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“µğ“Ÿ). adjectiveÂ»[probably contains a reduplicated form of ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜] all right, nothing wrong; happy, content.Â»ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ, ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ ğ“©ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»I'm all right, you're all right, I'm OK, you're OK (as book title) (01/04/95/FH/pc:ok: -ğ“µğ“˜).Â»ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“™Â»we're happy (RBn12-03p5). ğ“²ğ“£ğ“§ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ªğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“™Â»we are happy in our home (RBn12-03p5). â€¢Â»adj, adv peaceful(ly), calm(ly), at rest, still (as a lake), in harmony, harmonious(ly), not worried, satisfied.Â»ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“µğ“ŸÂ»he's calm (BE2.102; FH:prod). ğ“·ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“£ğ“©ğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“»ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ ğ“ªğ“˜ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“œğ“£Í˜Â»I want to thank you for this good life (literally, 'I am grateful, I walk on this earth peacefully') (RBn10-10:JW). ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“œğ“£Í˜ ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“œğ“˜Â»I want to go on in peace, harmony (RBn22-17).

ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜, ğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜). verbÂ»[regularÂ£, _ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜] (intransitive)Â»move, change (as the weather)Â»(FH:ok) ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“°ğ“™Â»let's move, let's start (RBn12-11). ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“¯ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“˜?Â»why is this dog moving around so much? â€¢ go on, continue.Â»ğ“¤ğ“ªğ“²ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“ŸÂ»I've been going on for a long time (MOJ). â€¢Â»start.Â»ğ“ªğ“µğ“£ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“˜Â»start the car (literally, 'make the car start') (RBn2-MOJ/p35; 03/14/95/FH/pc:ok). ğ“ªğ“µğ“£ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ?Â»is the car started? ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“ªğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ ğ“ªğ“¨ğ“š). verb phraseÂ»be in the armed forces, be a member of the military service; go to warÂ»(BE2.4; 01/06/95/FH/pc:ok). noun Â»armed forces; any branch of the military service.

ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿğ“¯ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜. â‰  Â»adjectiveÂ»quarrelsome (literally, 'fights continually').Â»ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¤'ğ“ª ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿğ“¯ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»she's a quarrelsome woman.

ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“ª â‰  (variant of ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ª).

ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜. â‰  Â»v,Â»adjectiveÂ»[stat.] (intransitive)Â»burn; burned.Â»ğ“µğ“Ÿğ“ºğ“Ÿ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜Â»I burned my tongue (01/09/95/FH/pc:okc; BE2.13). ğ“ªğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜, ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“œğ“˜Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»the cooking must be burning, because it's smelling (FH). ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜ ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“ŸÂ»you burned the meat (literally, 'you caused meat burning') (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod). ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»the meat's burned (01/09/95/FH/pc:prod; BE2.13).

ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ª â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“ª).Â»noun Â»[probably ğ“°ğ“˜- instrÂ»+ ğ“§ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ª]Â»meat gravy, popular Osage dish made of boiled meatÂ»(BE2.86; FH). [Meat is cut up, washed, rinsed, and stored in a pot overnight. The next day the meat is rinsed off then covered with the rinse water and juices that have exuded and accumulated in the pot. Salt and pepper are added, and the meat is boiled until almost dry, whereupon bacon grease and flour are added and the entire mixture is browned. Water is then added to achieve gravy consistency (FH).]

ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ªğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ªğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜, ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ªğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜). noun Â»schoolÂ»(03/08/95/MREI/pc:ok: short final ğ“˜).Â»[Borrowed from Pawnee ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“¶ğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜Â»'school'Â»(Douglas Parks). The Pawnee word may have entered Osage at different times in different forms, with or without preaspiration of the stops (ğ“¡)ğ“°Â»and (ğ“¡)ğ“¬Â»and with a long or short vowel ğ“˜Â»or ğ“˜; it is losing or has lost the preaspiration in (ğ“¡)ğ“°Â»and (ğ“¡)ğ“¬.] ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ªğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£Â»school building (03/08/95/MREI/pc). ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ªğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜Â»go to school [singular addressee]. ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ªğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ğ“¬ğ“£Â»go to school [plural addressee]. ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ªğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜Â»school is dismissed [said at the close of the school day], school is out [for the summer] (03/08/95/MREI/pc:okc; BE2.116). ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“£Í˜ğ“¸ğ“²ğ“£ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ, ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ªğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“œğ“£Í˜ğ“œğ“Ÿ ğ“©ğ“™Â»the children get up early, I take them to school (02/27/95/JS/pc:okc; BE2.131). ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ªğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“¯ğ“ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“šğ“¯ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“£Â»when you're going off to school, take care of yourself.

ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“Ÿğ“»ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“£ â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“£) indef pronpÂ»anything; any other thing, anything else (literally, 'thing other also'); everything else, all other things.Â»ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“ªğ“¸ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“Ÿğ“»ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“£ ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜Â»[expected Mod. ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¡ğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“£. â‰  Â»indef pronp whatever; everything, anything at all.Â»ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¡ğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“¸ğ“Ÿ ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“œğ“˜Â»whatever it is, I want you to fix it for them. ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¡ğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“¸ğ“Ÿ ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“œğ“˜Â»anything at all, I want you to fix it for them; everything, I want you to fix it for them.

ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“£ğ“œğ“£ğ“§ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ. â‰  Â»interr/indef vpÂ»guess what? (literally, 'I'm thinking something'). [Contains 'standing' positional article ğ“²ğ“Ÿ.] ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“£ğ“œğ“£ğ“§ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ guess what?

ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“£ğ“µğ“£ğ“§ğ“˜Í˜. â‰  Â»indef vpÂ»[syncopatingÂ£, ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“£_ğ“µğ“£ğ“§ğ“˜Í˜] (intransitive)Â»think about or consider something, have something on one's mind. ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“ªğ“²ğ“£. â‰  Â»indef pronp many things, lots of things; disorderly abundance; mixture of items that are out of order, trashy mixture; messÂ»(PM/pc:prod; 04/17/95/LS/pc:ok).

ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ğ“®ğ“¤ğ“˜. â‰  Â»indef pronÂ»what-do-you-call-it, thingamajig, whachamacallit; who's-it, what's-his-name, what's-her-name; item, thing, something (BE2.154; RBn2-MOJ/p14; 04/28/95/LS/pc:okc ; FH:ok). ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“Ÿ â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“£). adj,Â»v [uninflected] (be) well.Â»ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“Ÿ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»I [sitting] am well. ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“ŸÂ»I [moving] am well; I have been well. ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“Ÿ ğ“©ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ?Â»are you well? ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“°ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ?Â»are you [standing] well? ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ?Â»are you [moving] well? ğ“°ğ“ª â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜).Â»adverbÂ»barely, hardly, only to a limited degree or barely representative amount. ğ“£ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“˜Â»don't laugh so much (literally, 'that laughing, like barely make it') (ERE/2/95/pc). ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“©ğ“£ğ“µğ“ŸÂ»barely allow to live. ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ğ“¡ğ“Ÿ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“ª ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“˜!Â»don't sleep so much! ğ“°ğ“ªğ“˜ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“°ğ“ªğ“Ÿ, ğ“°ğ“ª). adj,Â»pronÂ»any.Â»ğ“°ğ“ªğ“»ğ“¶ ğ“°ğ“ªğ“˜ ğ“·ğ“Ÿğ“¯ğ“ğ“¶ğ“·ğ“£Í˜?Â»did you sell any meat pies? ğ“°ğ“ªğ“˜ â‰  (variant of ğ“°ğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜).

ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜, ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“Ÿ, ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“£Í˜, ğ“°ğ“« â‰  (variants of ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ).

ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ). noun Â»[ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜Â»'stubby' (?) (root not attested elsewhere in Mod. ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜, ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“£Í˜, ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“Ÿ, ğ“°ğ“«). verbÂ»[syncopatingÂ£ fortisizing stop stem, _ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ] (transitive)Â»see, observe, watchÂ»(RBn10-15). [Truncated variants ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜, ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“£Í˜, ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“Ÿ, ğ“°ğ“«Â»occur frequently in combination with other words, as in ğ“Ÿğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“°ğ“«ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»'Look Only at Her' (personal name) and ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“Ÿğ“²ğ“£Â»'store'.] ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»I watch it.Â»ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»you watch it.Â»ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»he watches it. ğ“˜Í˜ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ we watch it. ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ ğ“œğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“ŸÂ»I'm going to see it (02/22/95/FH/pc:prod orig). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“™ ğ“²ğ“ŸÂ»let's go watch them dance [singular addressee] (RBn10-12:JW). ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“©ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ ğ“·ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“£ğ“©ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“Ÿ, ğ“£ğ“§ğ“«ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»I want to thank you children for watching my son dance. ğ“¤ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“£Í˜ğ“Ÿğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜, ğ“¤ğ“ªğ“Ÿ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ ğ“²ğ“ŸÂ»he followed the butterflies so that he could watch them (RBn15-02; FH:ok). â€¢Â»(intransitive, transitive)Â»look, look at, on, or uponÂ»(02/22/95/FH/pc:okc). ğ“°ğ“« ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“ŸÂ»I'm looking (02/22/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.81). ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“£Í˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“ºğ“Ÿ ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜Â»when I look at it, it makes me dizzy (RBn10-7:JW). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»someone is looking at us; something is looking at us; someone is staring at us (02/22/95/FH/pc:okc). ğ“°ğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜ ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜Â»look at him/her/that. ğ“¤ğ“ªğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“©ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜Â»look at that man farther over there. ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“¨ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¸ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Â»look, the weather is good (RBn1-33).

ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“µğ“Ÿ. â‰  Â»verbÂ»[syncopatingÂ£, ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ (ğ“˜)_ğ“µğ“Ÿ] (intransitive)Â»go looking.Â»ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“µğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»he started off to see what he could see (literally, 'and he immediately went looking') (RBn15-03).

ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“Ÿ â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“™). verbÂ»[uninflected or regularÂ£, ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“˜_ğ“µğ“Ÿ] [ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»+ ğ“·ğ“˜-Â»valÂ»+ ğ“µğ“ŸÂ»cau]Â»(intransitive)Â»be worth looking at (literally, 'causes people to look at it'). ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“™ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Â»it's worth looking at (1/20/83/p5). â€¢Â»make someone look or appear a certain way, look like or appear.Â»ğ“§ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“™Â»he looks like he's drunk (02/22/95/FH/pc:ma). ğ“²ğ“Ÿğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“™Â»you look like you just got up (02/22/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.82). ğ“¸ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“™Â»it makes you look sloppy. ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“Ÿğ“¡ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“™Â»the chair looks weak (BE2.152; 03/16/95/JS/pc:ok).

ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ â‰  Â»(variant of ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ).

ğ“°ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“°ğ“¸ğ“˜, ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜). positÂ»positional article for a singular animate standing entity (usually not the subjectÂ»of a verb describing action). ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“°ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“¡ğ“¶ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“Ÿğ“˜Â»tell the person standing there to come here. ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“·ğ“˜ ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ ğ“°ğ“¸ğ“˜ ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ ğ“£ğ“°ğ“˜?Â»whose horse is that over there? ğ“°ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“˜ â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“˜). ppnÂ»[ğ“°ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜Â»+ ğ“¡ğ“˜] until, from.Â»ğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“˜Â»to this day (RBn16-02). ğ“µğ“Ÿğ“°ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“˜/ğ“µğ“Ÿğ“°ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“˜Â»from here on; from now on.

ğ“·ğ“˜- â‰  prnmÂ»3rd person plural patient pronominal ('they', subject of stative verb [can be omitted]; 'them', object of active verbs).Â»ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“µğ“˜Â»he wants it for them. ğ“Ÿ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“˜Â»make her invite them. ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜!Â»watch over them [singular or plural addressees]! Mary, Darlene ğ“ªğ“©ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“œğ“Ÿ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“ªğ“µğ“ªğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“œğ“˜Â»I want Mary and Darlene to oversee this dinner (FH:prod). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“¡ğ“£ ğ“»ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“ªÍ˜ ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“˜Í˜ğ“§ğ“Ÿ ğ“¡ğ“˜Í˜ğ“©ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“ºğ“Ÿ ğ“ªğ“§ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¬ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“œğ“˜Â»before the dances start, first I want [them] to put him in jail (more literally, '.Â».Â». ğ“·ğ“˜-Â».Â».Â».Â»ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“£ â‰  Â»(variant: ğ“·ğ“˜). prnmÂ»1st person plural patient pronominal ('we', subject of stative verbs; 'us', object of active verbs).Â»ğ“ªğ“µğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»he's bossing us around [ğ“ªğ“µğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“£ â‰¤ ğ“·ğ“˜- .Â».Â». ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“£ 'us' + ğ“ªğ“µğ“ªğ“µğ“Ÿ] (FH:prod). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“£Â»watch over us [ğ“·ğ“˜- .Â».Â». ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“£ 'us' + ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ] (FH/08/01/01/pc). ğ“¡ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“£ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ?Â»when are you all going to come see us? (03/09/95/FH/pc). ğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“¡ğ“¶ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£ ğ“»ğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“Ÿ ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“œğ“˜Â»I want you to be with us a long time [ğ“»ğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“ŸÂ»â‰¤ ğ“·ğ“˜-Â»'us' + ğ“µğ“˜-Â»'you' + ğ“»ğ“ªğ“§ğ“ŸÂ»'accompany'] (RBn12-10/MOJ). ğ“»ğ“ªğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“Ÿ ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£Í˜Â»you ought to go with us.

ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ). noun Â»skirt with ribbon work or other decorations.Â»ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“·ğ“£ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜Â»my skirt is short (03/10/95/PM/pc; FH:4/24/96/pc). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“ªğ“¡ğ“£ğ“»ğ“£Â»my skirt does not go around.

ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£. â‰  Â»verbÂ»[regularÂ£, ğ“·ğ“˜_ğ“²ğ“£] dance.Â»ğ“˜ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ ~ ğ“˜ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£Â»I dance. ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ you dance. ğ“˜Í˜ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ we [plural] dance. ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“Ÿ ğ“·ğ“Ÿğ“·ğ“£ğ“©ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¡ğ“Ÿ, ğ“£ğ“§ğ“«ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»I want to thank you children for watching my son dance. ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“¬ğ“£ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»she is a good [skilled] dancer (literally, 'she knows how to dance'). ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“§ğ“£ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ, ğ“˜Í˜ğ“µğ“£ğ“¯ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“°ğ“™Â»we've danced a long time, let's stop (BE2.29). ğ“˜Í˜ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“µğ“£ğ“ŸÂ»dance for me (FH/11/17/01/pc:ok: ğ“˜ğ“·ğ“˜). â€¢Â»noun Â»dance.Â»ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“« ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“™ ğ“²ğ“ŸÂ»let's go see the dance [singular addressee]. ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“£Í˜ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ ğ“¡ğ“¶ğ“»ğ“˜ ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜Â»this dance Osages had a long time (literally, 'Osages had a dance, a long time they've had this one') (PM/7/7/94). ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“ºğ“Ÿ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“« ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“™ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“™Â»we are going for the night dance [to observe the dance]. ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“™ ğ“²ğ“ŸÂ»let's go to the dance [implies that we will dance]. ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“µğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¡ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“Ÿğ“°ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“£ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»it's almost time for the dance (FH/t116b).

ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“ªğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“ªğ“°ğ“˜, ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“ªğ“°ğ“˜). adjectiveÂ»straight; reliable, respectable, proper, honestÂ»(04/19/95/FH/pc). [Refers to a person's way of living rather than to conduct of the moment and hence is often used in admonishments (as in making one's ways straight, reforming, straightening out, going straight in one's behavior); contrasts with ğ“ªğ“µğ“ªğ“°ğ“˜Í˜, which refers to immediate behavior or conduct of the moment and thus may be used, for example, to scold childen for their current actions.] ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“ªğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¨ğ“šÂ»keep yourself straight (BE2.129). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“ªğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“§ğ“˜ğ“µğ“£Í˜Â»keep yourself straight (FH:4/24/96/prod). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“ªğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“§ğ“™Â»I behave myself/carry myself straight (RBn; MREI/01/11/93?). ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“»ğ“£Í˜ ğ“·ğ“£ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“ªğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“©ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“˜ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“£ğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¸ğ“Ÿ ğ“¤ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“œğ“˜Â»I want you to make my children proper people (RBn19-06). ğ“©ğ“£ğ“¤ğ“˜ğ“¯ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“ªğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“£ ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜Â»he's proper/reliable/good/respectable (RBn22-17). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“ªğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¨ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“¯ğ“ŸÂ»I'll behave myself (MOJ-11-19-83). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“®ğ“™ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“ªğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“£ğ“¬ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“ŸÂ»they knew the bear was honest/respectable (RBn16-02). â€¢Â»adverbÂ»clearly, straight, properly, truthfully.Â»ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“µğ“ªğ“°ğ“˜Í˜Â»speak clearly, straight or truthfully (FH).

ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“ªğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“¬ğ“˜ â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¡ğ“ªğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“¬ğ“˜). noun Â»pistolÂ»(literally, 'round gun') (02/03/95/FH/pc:ok; RBn3-MOJ/p5; 04/11/95/LS/pc:uk; BE2.103). [Refers to the round chamber in pistols as opposed to the rectangular chamber in rifles and shotguns (except breech-loading ones) in early days. Pistols were the first guns to have round chambers.]

ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“Ÿğ“²ğ“£. â‰  Â»noun Â»[ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ + ğ“²ğ“£] store, shop, place where things are exhibited (literally, 'house in which to look at things'). ğ““ğ“˜ğ“©ğ“˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“£ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“µğ“Ÿ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“Ÿğ“²ğ“£ ğ“²ğ“Ÿ?Â»what did John see in the store?

ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“«, ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“£Í˜, ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“Ÿ). verbÂ»[conjug. unknown] [wa- valÂ»+ ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“¬ğ“Ÿ] (intransitive)Â»see or watch people or events,Â»look on at an event (e.g., a dance [RB])Â»(03/02/95/FH/pc:okc). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“« ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“™ ğ“µğ“ŸÂ»we are going to see the dance (03/02/95/FH/pc; BE2.97).Â»ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ğ“Ÿ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“« ğ“¯ğ“²ğ“Ÿ ğ“©ğ“˜Í˜ ğ“°ğ“˜ ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“™Â»you're always going to go to [to watch] dances (MSB-9-3-82). ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“²ğ“£ ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“ªÍ˜ğ“ŸÂ»watch the dances. noun Â»spectators, onlookers, audience, publicÂ»(03/14/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.125).

ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“¸ğ“˜ğ“ºğ“¶ â‰  Â»(variants:Â»ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ğ“ºğ“¶, ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜ğ“ºğ“¶, ğ“·ğ“˜ğ“°ğ“¤ğ“¸ğ“˜Í˜ğ“ºğ“¶). noun Â»dried corn, preparation of dried corn soupÂ»(LS; FH/09/11/01/pc:ok; RBn1-14). [Some families dried corn on the ear, tying it up with twine to hang it a cob at a time. The children would be in charge of keeping the flies off during the day, and the ears would be taken inside at night if it had been drying outside on tables. If hanging on a screened-in porch, it would be left about three days to dry.]

ğ“·ğ“£ğ“²ğ“£ğ“»ğ“ª â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“·ğ“£ğ“²ğ“£ğ“»ğ“ªğ“Ÿ). noun Â»my sister's daughter (used only when speaker is male; more precise than English 'my niece'); my father's sister's daughter (used when speaker is male or female; more precise than English 'my cousin'). ğ“·ğ“£ğ“²ğ“£Í˜ğ“°ğ“ª. â‰  Â»noun Â»my older brother (oldest of speaker's brothers, not necessarily older than the speaker; used only when speaker is female; more precise than English 'my older brother') (01/09/95/FH/pc:ok).

ğ“·ğ“£ğ“²ğ“ªğ“¯ğ“¤ğ“˜. â‰  Â»noun Â»my sister's son, my wife's brother's son (used only when speaker is male; more precise than English 'my nephew') (02/27/95/FH/pc:ok; BE2.92); my brother's son (used only when speaker is female; more precise than English 'my nephew'); son of my father's sister (my paternal aunt's son; used when speaker is male or female; more precise than English 'my cousin'); my grandchild (my granddaughter or my grandson; used when speaker is male or female) (04/17/95/LS/pc; 04/18/95/FH/pc:ok). [Historically, 'grandchild' is an unexpected gloss (perhaps used only by extension to one's grandniece or grandnephew: i.e., one's sibling's grandchild?).]

ğ“·ğ“£ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ â‰  Â»(variant:Â»ğ“·ğ“£ğ“°ğ“£Í˜ğ“¤ğ“Ÿ). noun Â»my older sister (used when speaker is male or female); my sister (loosely used mutually among unrelated younger and older female speakers to show respect); my wife (literally, 'my sister'; used to refer to speaker's wife when they have no children and possibly to address her)Â»(RBn12-12; 03/16/95/MREI/pc:ok; BE2.158). [This is the default vocative 'sister' term; the person so addressed need not be older than the speaker. As illustration of this, Mrs. Josephine Walker always called Mrs. Frances Holding, who was younger, ğ“·ğ“£ğ“°ğ“˜Í˜ğ“¤ğ“ŸÂ»(FH10/13/96). When used to mean 'older sister', the sister in question may be either older than the speaker or the oldest of the group of sisters.]

ğ“ºğ“˜Í˜. â‰  Â»noun Â»country, prairie (FH); timbersÂ»[not 'timbers' or 'woods' in Mod. Osage, possibly archaic?]. ğ“ºğ“˜Í˜ğ“²ğ“ŸÂ»a valley with trees, a grove of trees (RBn19, unconfirmed).
